com.thinkaurelius.titan.core
Interface TypeMaker

public interface TypeMaker

TypeMaker is a factory for TitanTypes. TitanTypes can be configured to provide data verification, better storage efficiency, and higher performance. The TitanType defines the schema for all TitanRelations of that type.
All user defined types are configured using a TypeMaker instance returned by TitanTransaction.makeType(). Hence, types are defined within the context of a transaction like every other object in a TitanGraph. The TypeMaker is used to create both: property keys and edge labels using either makePropertyKey() or makeEdgeLabel(), respectively. Some of the methods in TypeMaker are only applicable to one or the other.
Most configuration options provided by the methods of this class are optional and default values are assumed as documented for the particular methods. However, one must call name(String) to define the unqiue name of the type. When defining property keys, one must also configure the data type using dataType(Class).

Author:
Matthias Bröcheler (http://www.matthiasb.com)
See Also:
TitanType, Titan Type Wiki

TypeMaker functional()
Configures the type to be functional. By default, the type is non-functional.

Returns:
this type maker
See Also:
TitanType.isFunctional()

functional

TypeMaker functional(boolean locking)
Configures the type to be functional and whether the database should acquire a lock when creating or updating relation instances of this type. If locking is set to true, which is the default when invoking functional(), then the database will acquire a lock an updated or created relation to ensure no data is blindly overwritten. If locking is set to false, then no lock is acquired. Acquiring locks ensures data consistency but comes at the expense of having to acquire a lock and failing transactions when there is lock contention or the lock could not be acquired for other reasons.

Returns:
this type maker

directed

TypeMaker directed()
Configures the type to be directed. This only applies to edge labels. By default, the type is directed.

Returns:
this type maker
See Also:
TitanLabel.isDirected()

Configures the type to be unidirected. This only applies to edge labels. By default, the type is directed.

simple

TypeMaker simple()
Configures the type to be simple, which means that relation instances of the type do not support incident properties. By default, the type is not simple and allows incident properties.

Returns:
this type maker
See Also:

Returns:
this type maker
See Also:
TypeGroup

primaryKey

TypeMaker primaryKey(TitanType... types)
Configures the composite primary key for this type. This only applies to edge labels. Specifying the primary key of a type allows edges of this type to be efficiently retrieved in the order of the key.
For instance, if the edge label friend has the primary key (since), which is a property key with a timestamp data type, then one can efficiently retrieve all edges with label friend in a specified time interval using TitanQuery.interval(TitanKey, Comparable, Comparable).
In other words, relations are stored on disk in the order of the configured primary key. The primary key is empty by default. TitanTypes used in the primary key must be either property keys or unidirected edge lables. Also, they must be simple (TitanType.isSimple()) and functional (TitanType.isFunctional()).

Parameters:
types - TitanTypes composing the primary key. The order is relevant.
Returns:
this type maker

signature

TypeMaker signature(TitanType... types)
Configures the signature of this type. This only applies to edge labels. Specifying the signature of a type tells the graph database to expect that edges of this type always have or are likely to have an incident property or unidirected edge of the type included in the signature. This allows the graph database to store such edges more compactly and retrieve them more quickly.
For instance, if all edges with label friend have a property with key createdOn, then specifying (createdOn) as the signature for type friend allows friend edges to be stored more efficiently.
TitanTypes used in the signature must be either property keys or unidirected edge lables. Also, they must be simple (TitanType.isSimple()) and functional (TitanType.isFunctional()).
The signature should not contain any types already included in the primary key. The primary key provides the same storage and retrieval efficiency.
The signature is empty by default.

Parameters:
types - TitanTypes composing the primary key. The order is irrelevant.
Returns:
this type maker

unique

TypeMaker unique()
Configures the type to be unqiue, which means that each value for a property of this type is uniquely associated with a vertex. This only applies to property keys. By default, the type is not unique.

Returns:
this type maker
See Also:
TitanKey.isUnique()

indexed

TypeMaker indexed()
Configures instances of this type to be indexed. This only applies to property keys. By default, the type is not indexed.

Returns:
this type maker
See Also:
TitanKey.hasIndex()

dataType

TypeMaker dataType(Class<?> clazz)
Configures the data type for this type. This only applies to property keys. Property instances for this key will only accept attribute values that are instances of this class. Every property key must have its data type configured. Setting the data type to Object.class allows any type of attribute but comes at the expense of longer serialization because class information is stored with the attribute value.

Parameters:
clazz - Data type to be configured.
Returns:
this type maker
See Also:
TitanKey.getDataType()

makeEdgeLabel

Returns:
New edge label
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if the name is already in use or if other configurations are invalid.
